Pulsars are rotating neutron stars. Most neutron stars discovered today are in the form of radio pulsars. They are called radio pulsars because they emit radio waves. We can simply connect a radio telescope to a loud speaker and hear a pulsar. Pulsars sound like someone persistently knocking. So in short, we can hear a pulsar knock.

Quran, Chapter no. 86 (Surah At-Taariq : Chapter of Pulsar), Verse no. 1-3:
By the sky and the night knocker.
وَٱلسَّمَآءِ وَٱلطَّارِقِ (1)
And what can make you know what is the night knocker?
(2)وَمَآ أَدْرَىٰكَ مَا ٱلطَّارِقُ
˹It is˺ the star of piercing brightness.
(3)ٱلنَّجْمُ ٱلثَّاقِبُ

"Taariq الطَّارِقُ" means the one who knocks. The Arabic word "Thuqb ثقب" means a hole; "Thaaqib ثَّاقِبُ" means the one who makes a hole. The Quran is describing a knocking star that makes a hole (Distorted Spacetime).

Pulsars are rotating neutron stars. As more matter falls into a neutron star its mass increases, and as its mass increases its gravity increases. But gravity is curvature of spacetime. A neutron star distorts spacetime. The more matter falls into a neutron star the more distortion it makes. A point will be reached where distortion would have grown so much that it makes a hole in spacetime.

The present explanation of Neutron Stars has no experimental evidence and is untestable as a hypothesis. The lab evidence reveals that neutrons outside of the nucleus of an atom decay into a proton, electron and a neutrino within 15 minutes. Gravity is a force that acts between two bodies and the acceptance that it can act on itself is again untested and frankly untestable. As for mathematical evidence, well, mathematics is an abstraction and as such does not prove the truthfulness of a model, though it does prove the usefulness of a model.



Einstein's gravity model of the universe is in a similar position as Ptolemy's geocentric model just prior to Copernicus. Dark Energy/Matter are the equivalent of Ptolemy's epicycles which were ad hoc adjustments to keep a failing model relevant. When Einstein brilliantly derived his gravity model it was the present consensus that space was void of all matter and that planets were isolated islands. We now know that this is not so, that planets are connected via electric currents, magnetic fields and gravity, with the latter being the weakest by 10^39 times to an electric field. Many are the observational discrepancies with respect to the Einstein model and as such they are in effect falsifications of said model. Sadly, even within science there can be a dogmatic attitude and even questioning Einstein's model will cause one to be derided and demeaned, and as such, regardless of the validity of a paper you write, it will not get published.



In a nutshell, what he presents is a good explanation of the standard model, but considering the number of observational discrepancies that the standard model did not predict, should one still be clinging to it. It is skepticism that keeps science honest, something that seems lost upon those adherents of the standard model.

A neutron star has a magnetic field strength in the order of 100 million ~ 1 quadrillion times that of Earth's. Tibet (/tɪˈbɛt/ (  listen); Tibetan: བོད་, Wylie: bod, ZYPY: Poi, Lhasa dialect IPA: pʰøː˨˧˩; Chinese: 西藏; pinyin: Xīzàng /ɕi⁵⁵ t͡sɑŋ⁵¹/) is a historical region covering much of the Tibetan Plateau in Central Asia. It is the traditional homeland of the Tibetan people as well as some other ethnic groups such as Monpa, Qiang, and Lhoba peoples and is now also inhabited by considerable numbers of Han Chinese and Hui people. Tibet is the highest region on Earth, with an average elevation of 4,900 metres (16,000 ft).[citation needed] The highest elevation in Tibet is Mount Everest, Earth's highest mountain, rising 8,848 m (29,029 ft) above sea level.        "Greater Tibet" as claimed by Tibetan exile groups Tibetan autonomous areas, as designated by China Tibet Autonomous Region, within ChinaChinese-controlled, claimed by India as part of Aksai ChinIndian-controlled, parts claimed by China as South TibetOther areas historically within the Tibetan cultural sphereTibet "Tibet" in the Tibetan (top) and Chinese (bottom) scriptsChinese nameChinese西藏Literal meaning"Western Tsang"TranscriptionsStandard MandarinHanyu PinyinXīzàngWade–GilesHsi1-tsang4IPA[ɕí.tsâŋ]WuRomanizationxi55 zaan21HakkaRomanizationSî-tshôngYue: CantoneseJyutpingsai1 zong6Southern MinHokkien POJSe-chōngTeochew Peng'imSai-tsăngEastern MinFuzhou BUCSă̤-câungMiddle ChineseMiddle ChineseSei-dzangTibetan nameTibetanབོད་TranscriptionsWyliebodTibetan PinyinPoiThe Tibetan Empire emerged in the 7th century, but with the fall of the empire the region soon divided into a variety of territories. The bulk of western and central Tibet (Ü-Tsang) was often at least nominally unified under a series of Tibetan governments in Lhasa, Shigatse, or nearby locations; these governments were at various times under Mongoland Chinese overlordship. Thus Tibet remained a suzerainty of the Mongol and later Chinese rulers in Nanjing and Beijing, with reasonable autonomy given to the Tibetan leaders.[1] The eastern regions of Kham and Amdo often maintained a more decentralized indigenous political structure, being divided among a number of small principalities and tribal groups, while also often falling more directly under Chinese rule after the Battle of Chamdo. Most of this area was eventually incorporated into the Chinese provinces of Sichuan and Qinghai. The current borders of Tibet were generally established in the 18th century.[2]Following the Xinhai Revolution against the Qing dynasty in 1912, Qing soldiers were disarmed and escorted out of Tibet Area (Ü-Tsang). The region subsequently declared its independence in 1913 without recognition by the subsequent Chinese Republican government.[3] Later, Lhasa took control of the western part of Xikang, China. The region maintained its autonomy until 1951 when, following the Battle of Chamdo, Tibet became incorporated into the People's Republic of China, and the previous Tibetan government was abolished in 1959 after a failed uprising.[4] Today, China governs western and central Tibet as the Tibet Autonomous Region while the eastern areas are now mostly ethnic autonomous prefectures within Sichuan, Qinghai and other neighbouring provinces. There are tensions regarding Tibet's political status[5] and dissident groups that are active in exile.[6] Tibetan activists in Tibet have been arrested or tortured.[7]The economy of Tibet is dominated by subsistence agriculture, though tourism has become a growing industry in recent decades. The dominant religion in Tibet is Tibetan Buddhism; in addition there is Bön, which is similar to Tibetan Buddhism,[8] and there are also Tibetan Muslims and Christian minorities. Tibetan Buddhism is a primary influence on the art, music, and festivals of the region. Tibetan architecture reflects Chinese and Indian influences. Staple foods in Tibet are roasted barley, yak meat, and butter tea.

Iron can fuse to form heavier elements. It's just that unlike the lighter atoms, the stars loses energy trying to fuse Iron so the that is the cause of the rapid collapse of the core (the video originally states that the star "can't" fuse iron. This is sorta false in the sense that it can, it just loses energy doing so). heavier elements are formed during this rapid collapse and resulting supernova. I'm pretty sure iron does fuse to form heavior elements, but as soon as iron is produced, the star is throwing energy into a drain trying to fuse something that produces less energy then needed. So the pressure the core needs to resist gravity rapidly fails.

So iron can and is being fused into heavier elements at the end of the Star's lifetime, it just happens very quickly because once enough iron is present, the star collapses since Iron becomes a energy sink that it can get nothing from to survive the crushing gravity.

You said Iron cannot fuse into another element, but that's not true. Its not impossible to fuse Iron, however the nuclear reaction would require more energy to fuse than would be released by the fusion process. That only means that the fusion of Iron would sap energy from the star instead of adding to the radiation pressure. Since everything in nature seems to take the path of least resistance, we don't see this happen naturally. However (theoretically) if we had the technology to generate enough energy, it would be possible to fuse Iron with another lighter element.

This video contains multiple serious inaccuracies!  Stars do not develop 'layers', as there are intense currents moving everything around and mixing everything up.  Our sun does not have a ball of helium at its center.  The helium is dispersed throughout.  Also, iron DOES fuse inside of stars!  But, when iron fuses, it releases less energy than it requires for the fusion to take place.  Which reduces, rather than increases, the total amount of energy in the star.  All lighter elements release more energy when they fuse, which fuels further fusion.  Once a star starts fusing iron, it starts losing overall energy, which is what eventually causes the radiation pressure to drop below the crushing force of gravity.  I'm no astrophysicist, so I imagine there are many other inaccuracies and mistakes, but I don't know enough to identify them.

Everything's cool, just one notification for you, guys - the Polish translation has several errors (mostly grammatical). One of those is quite major (most Poles are going to be extremely confused by it): silicon isn't called "silikon" here - "silikon" is a colloquial name for breast augmentation and that's pretty much the only application of it around here. The proper name of the element is "krzem".

Here's a reference: https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/krzem

Actually, Iron CAN fuse to other heavier atoms. This is answered by the question, why is there Gold on earth - or any other element heavier than iron? All the matter in the Universe, with some very few exceptions was once created inside a star - the difference between big gang nucleosynthesis and stellar nuclearsynthesis. It is true that inside the core of a star, like our sun for example, you will not see a nucleosynthesis beyond Iron. It simply can't really happen for the reasons mentioned in the video. However, if a star is big enough, let us say 10 times the mass of our Sun, it can fuse iron and all the other materials together that we see today. This happens at the near end of the life time of a very massive star. When they become super or even hyper nova. For a very short moment the temperature and preasure in the outer layers of the star become so high that they allow the fusion of heavier atoms than iron up to Uranium which is the natural border. A heavier star will have more preasure and a higher temperature, they will also be brighter emitting more radiation. The fusion at the end of the cycle will be shorter and shorter. Where the fusion of Hydrogen to Helium takes place within a few million years the fusion of elements leading to Uranium happens in a couple of seconds! For the purpose of this video it is probably enough to stop with iron, as they are not facutally wrong, as far as you stay with smaller stars, however it should be important to keep in mind that yeah, the other elements we have today also come from stars. If I remember right.  The reason fusion in stars stops at iron is because it's the first element that absorbs more energy then is released by the fusion reaction.  So it starts eating up the energy of the radiation pressure and the whole system collapses.  It's silly to suggest that iron can not fuse to make heavier elements.  That is exactly what happens in a super nova.  It is interesting to think that all elements heavier than iron are created in a very big explosion in a very short amount of time.I'm also a little mind fucked now.  The video describes the core of a neutron star as possibly being quark plasma.  Yet the early moments of the universe are described by the same state of matter.  So, on the one hand you have an incredibly stable object like a neutron star and on the other you have the "neutron star core-like" state of the early universe being ripped apart by the hyper-inflation of space-time.  It boggles the mind...

Its not that iron cant fuse into bigger elements, its that doing so is endothermic, not exothermic. In other words, iron fusion doesnt make more energy than it absorbs. So the balance is thrown off and the star's gravity quickly overpowers the stars pressure.

However, in the resulting super nova, the iron IS fused into higher elements. And those elements are fused into yet higher elements. And so forth, in tiny proportions, up to uranium. The highest naturally occurring element.

If anyone's wondering why a neutron star sheds its layers when it supernovas, it's because of the conservation of momentum. If the central core, which contains (I believe) the majority of the star's mass contracts, the outer layers must be released with a momentum equal to the contraction. This is because supposedly, the star begins "standing still", as the core contracts,  the outer layers can't just stay there. The star would technically have gained speed out of nowhere if the core contracts by itself. If the core moves inwards, everything that isn't the core has to move in the opposite way. If a magical hand pushed in the core's surface, that would be okay- because a hand is pushing it. In the case of a supernova, the outer layers that are being shed are playing the role of the hand.

That's not the best explanation because it's highly technical and reliant upon knowledge of the conservation of momentum in physics, but there you go, it's an explanation if you were wondering.

I feel like neutron stars and our understanding of the four fundamental forces don't jive.  A neutron star may be held in place by gravity, but the strong force still exists, because at the most outer layer of the star, iron atoms are still doing their thing. 

As I'm understanding this, the mechanics of something like the core of a neutron star hold information that could possibly link some of these fundamental forces together?  Obviously, that's what scientists are continuing to study with quantum physics.  And also, obviously as the penguin said, we don't have a clue what's going on at the core.

It's just like a feeling that we're looking at the tip of an iceberg with a neutron star.  That there's SO MUCH MORE to it that can help us understand the nature of the universe, but we just don't have the equations for it yet.  I wish a was good at math.

You and I are made of this stuff, and just look how violently powerful it can be. The end result is a neutron star with 400 billion times the gravity of earth. So that means, at only a distance of one thousand kilometres, the gravitational tidal forces with bifurcate you into a lower limb and upper torso, then the gravity will exceed the intermolecular forces that bind your flesh and turn you into a stream of atoms. It gets worse. The neutron star is spinning, and your atoms enter into the most violent orbit ever. Worse still, your atoms are then ripped apart as they get closer and melted by gravitys uncontrollable power onto the surface of the neutron star. Worse again, your atoms explode at nearly the speed of light and the electrons, protons that you now are shoot from the magnetic poles of the neutron star at nearly the speed of light, colliding with the supernova remnant to make gamma Rays. All that will be left of you is a rhythmic noise, much like a car engine that sounds like it has a magnetron attached to it. Finally, you rest in pieces.

Humans know zilch about the internal composition of the stars. What we think we know is based on what we detect on the surface of our own sun.
Even then, the mainstream view is erroneous.
From observations of the activity of our star, the surface is most likely NOT gaseous hydrogen. The "splash back" behavior of CMEs & destabilized plasma filaments strongly suggests that the state of the solar surface is the same as is now being proposed by NASA as a future rocket propellant - liquid metal hydrogen.

neutrons can exist outside the "island of Stability", 
or that matter can be compressed as described.

When their hydrogen becomes depleted, high mass stars convert helium atoms into carbon and oxygen, followed by the fusion of carbon and oxygen into neon, sodium, magnesium, sulfur and silicon. Later reactions transform these elements into calcium, iron, nickel, chromium, copper and others. When these old, large stars with depleted cores supernova, they create heavy elements (all the natural elements heavier than iron) and spew them into space, forming the basis for life.

A good, clear summary of what is known and thought about neutron stars.

The question I've been pondering is whether the compression of ions and electrons into neutrons by a neutron star actually constitutes a net addition of energy/mass to the particles or whether the particles are actually supercooled into neutrons by intense compression.

We usually assume that a neutron has slightly more energy/mass than the proton and electron combined, which is contained in the neutrino, but what if neutrons are actually frozen particles that 'thaw' once they are liberated from the isolated environment of the atomic nucleus?  You could say this is impossible due to insufficient energy to thaw them but energy-blueshifting could allow relatively long-wavelength photons to be absorbed by the neutron at a higher-frequency, which would thaw the neutron causing it to convert into proton, electron, and neutrino.

Allow me to say a few things in regards to the channel content and possibly even about the OVP(s) responsible for it [producing / publishing]. I must admit they are of an acceptable quality. Hypothetically, OVP could be an okay person inside -- the kind people who are tolerable. He might even volunteer his time at homeless shelters for seniors and minorities who are studying for final exams. 

All-in-all, I am pretty much satisfied here. After having watched every video on this channel, I noticed some strange things, however. This would later become a consistent theme throughout The Kurzgesagt platform. That's why I decided to document it here for science. Hopefully, someone can explain what's going on. Here's my thoughts, overall. These presentational social content productions authored by OVP, evoked many strange, unfamiliar, and what appears to be non-undesirable sensations. 

It felt like a good inner feeling instead of a negative one, but I was okay with this at the time. It was a very new and  interesting experience, -- certainly not bad. Definitely disturbing. It was perhaps the apparent silence in my head that was the most surprising side effect. The sudden unexplained absence of most the ordinary murderous voices in my head was frightening at first. Very disconcerting, to say the least. 

Any of these unexpected psychological anomalies notwithstanding, such as the reduction of usual feelings of malevolence, I feel alright.-- albeit, slightly shaken. Nevertheless, despite these unexplainable inherent peculiarities, the content here did not cause me pain or duress. In fact, not once throughout my entire viewing time here did I find myself wanting to suddenly kill over dead from some type of super rare instantly fatal spontaneous terminal visual/auditory cancer. 

In a nutshell, seldom are the moments where I experience not wanting to be shot into the center of the sun. It was definitely an acceptable production suite of social media. I feel pretty good. I even decided to put him on my list of people to not kill after taking over planet earth. I am very excited; to date, this is the first person ever added to the global neutral non-aggression list. It didn’t even exist until now, because I had always planned to destroy  the entirety of human life forms altogether. Apparently though, some of you hominids are okay in my book,  -- or in this case, a list with a single name on it. 

Who am I kidding? I was literally blown away here. Love the channel. Love the style. Love the format. The tone, the pacing, delivery. It’s perfect. To put it another way, this dude friggle-fracking rocks hard core mega caffeinated thunder beans, yo. Word? Bet! OVP like a straight up space ninja. Respect.

years ago Larry Niven wrote a great hard sci-fi called The Integral Trees, with a sequel called The Smoke Ring. the premise is that after a neutron star was formed it held a torus of gas in orbit in what we would consider "the goldilocks zone" where water is liquid and photons are close enough together for photosynthesis. therefore carbon/oxygen life forms in freefall, and is colonized by a handful of human explorers. i remembered reading it after watching your video. thanks again Kurzgesagt!
